About.title: About Me
About.p1: I'm *Yanis Mohamed-Amine Harrat*, an **energetic and social "bon vivant"** with a deep passion for understanding how technology works at its core. My journey is defined by a **double dimension**: balancing the technical rigor of **Systems & Networks (BTS SIO SISR)** with the advanced logic and algorithmic grit of **Ecole 42 Paris**. I don't just use tech; I deconstruct it, build it, and live it.
About.p2: From my first lines of code to **self-hosting** my own ecosystems, I've always been drawn to the **Open Source** philosophy. I believe in technology that is accessible, communal, and transparent. My interests are continuously evolving, currently centered around the frontiers of **AI** and **Cybersecurity**.
About.p3: Outside the terminal, I'm a **hyperactive sports enthusiast**. Whether I'm tackling a complex infrastructure problem or pushing my limits on the field, I bring the same "all-in" energy. I thrive on social connection and believe that the best solutions are born from collective intelligence and a positive, high-energy atmosphere.

network-infrastructure.name: Network Infrastructure (Cisco Masterclass)
network-infrastructure.description: Routing & Switching Architecture: VLAN, OSPF, Security
network-infrastructure.fullDescription: This project simulates the engineering of a high-performance multi-site enterprise network. The goal is to demonstrate total mastery of the **Cisco IOS** ecosystem: from L2 segmentation via **VLANs** to multi-site interconnectivity via dynamic **OSPF** routing. A true engineering lab, it highlights the design of redundant gateways and the securing of critical end-to-end flows.

achievements.0: Designed a network core segmented into 3 isolated VLANs (Server, Admin, Client)
achievements.2: Configured a point-to-point WAN link with OSPF Area 0 convergence
achievements.3: Secured L2 access and optimized via Spanning-Tree (Portfast)
achievements.4: Advanced flow verification via Routing Table inspection (RIB)

network-infrastructure.topology:
2R-2S topology simulating a link between two distant entities:

- **Site A (HQ)**: Hosts Router R1 and Switch S1 (VLAN 2: Servers, VLAN 3: Management).
- **Site B (Branch)**: Hosts Router R2 and Switch S2 (VLAN 4: Clients).

**Technical Flow**: The routers use OSPF to exchange routes dynamically, allowing branch clients to communicate with HQ resources through a secured backbone.

0.title: 1. L2 Segmentation (VLANs & Trunks)
0.description: To prevent service mixing, we create **VLANs** (isolated networks). On switches, user ports are in Access mode, while links between machines are in **Trunk (802.1Q)** mode: a true highway capable of carrying all these networks on a single cable.

1.title: 2. Gateways: Router-on-a-Stick
1.description: The router acts as the conductor. Using the **Router-on-a-Stick** approach, we transform a physical port into multiple **virtual sub-interfaces**. Each sub-interface becomes the default gateway for a VLAN, allowing traffic to pass from one service to another according to defined rules.

2.title: 3. WAN Backbone: OSPF Routing
2.description: How to link two distant sites? By using **OSPF (Open Shortest Path First)**. This dynamic routing protocol automatically calculates the best path between HQ and Branch. It propagates routes throughout the network, guaranteeing fast convergence and avoiding tedious manual configurations.

3.title: 4. Diagnostic & End-to-End Flow
3.description: It's time for the final test. We inspect the **RIB (Routing Table)** to confirm that the sites 'see' each other. A simple Ping then traverses the entire backbone: Branch Switch -> Remote Router -> WAN -> HQ Router -> Server. Connectivity is total.

vm-network-lab.name: Hybrid Infrastructure
vm-network-lab.description: Physical Cisco Backbone (CLI) & Windows Server Services (GUI)
vm-network-lab.fullDescription: This hybrid architecture merges the worlds of virtualization and physical hardware. On a **Mac (VMware)**, I deployed a full **Windows Server** environment. The power of this project lies in the interconnection: virtual interfaces join a physical backbone of **2 Cisco routers and 2 switches** to ensure authentication and services across a real multi-site topology.

achievements.0: Hybrid Orchestration: Bridging vNIC/Mac to physical Cisco terminals
achievements.1: Backbone Cisco (CLI): Advanced IOS configuration (VLANs, Trunks, OSPF)
achievements.2: Access Control (AD DS): Management via Organizational Units (**OU**) and **GPO**
achievements.3: Addressing & Resolution: DHCP Scopes and DNS Zones (GUI Management)
achievements.4: Inter-Site Resilience: OSPF convergence and cross-backbone authentication

vm-network-lab.topology:
Segmented 2R-2S infrastructure connecting two distinct sites:

- **Site A (HQ)**: Physical L2 Switch hosting the virtual AD DS server (the Mac).
- **Site B (Branch)**: Physical L2 Switch hosting the physical client.

**Service Bridging**: The physical Cisco backbone ensures the transport of identity flows. The client authenticates on the remote server through the WAN tunnel simulated by OSPF.

0.title: 1. Network Core: CLI Configuration
0.description: Everything starts with the hardware. Connected in **console** mode, I configure routers and switches via the terminal (**CLI**). We prepare VLANs, 802.1Q Trunks, and OSPF routing. It is this physical base that will allow virtual data from the Mac to travel to the remote client.

1.title: 2. Identity Services: AD DS
1.description: Once the network is stable, we deploy the intelligence. On Windows Server, we promote the domain and structure **Active Directory** with **Organizational Units (OU)**. This hierarchy allows applying targeted **GPO** (Group Policy Objects) to harden security and automate client configuration.

2.title: 3. Infrastructure & Resolution (DNS/DHCP)
2.description: For the client to find the server autonomously, we configure services via their dedicated consoles. **DHCP** distributes IP addresses through physical switches (via 'IP Helper' relay), while **DNS** maps names to IPs. Everything is managed visually for maximum reliability.

3.title: 4. Real/Virtual Synergy: The Flow Test
3.description: The final test validates hybrid communication: a physical client (Site B) requests its network settings. The request traverses the physical Cisco backbone, reaches the virtual server on the Mac, and receives its IP via the graphical interface. Successful session login confirms architecture integrity.

portfolio-v2.name: Portfolio V2
portfolio-v2.fullDescription: This second iteration of my portfolio is a technological showcase of my expertise in the modern web. The goal was to build an **ultra-performant**, **scalable**, and **secure** application by exploiting the latest advancements of Next.js 16. The project abandons monolithic architectures for a 'Feature-Oriented' structure, guaranteeing absolute code clarity and simplified maintenance.

achievements.0: High-performance hybrid rendering via React 19 Server Components
achievements.1: Aggressive data optimization with new Next.js 16 cache APIs
achievements.2: Modular 'Feature-First' architecture for total domain isolation
achievements.3: Custom Design System with Tailwind CSS and fluid Framer Motion animations
achievements.4: Lighthouse Score 100/100 (Performance, Accessibility, SEO, Best Practices)

portfolio-v2.topology:
The architecture rests on three fundamental pillars:

1. **Feature-Based structure**: Code is organized by business domains (Hero, Projects, Skills) rather than technical types.
2. **Compound Components**: Intensive use of the composition pattern to create rich and flexible interfaces.
3. **Isomorphic Data Layer**: A typed data flow consumed directly by server components to eliminate unnecessary client requests.

0.title: 1. Feature-Based Architecture
0.description: The project is structured around the `src/features/` folder. Each feature has its own components, types, and internal logic. This allows strict isolation: we can modify the 'Projects' system without risking impact on the 'Skills' system. This is the standard for scalable enterprise applications.

1.title: 2. Next.js 16: The 'use cache' Era
1.description: I implemented the new `'use cache'` directive of Next.js 16 to optimize data fetching. Coupling this with `cacheLife('max')`, project details are served instantly from Vercel's edge cache, offering reactivity equivalent to a local application.

2.title: 3. Composition Patterns (Radix-Style)
2.description: For the UI, I used the **Compound Components** pattern (via `Object.assign`). This allows building complex components like `ProjectDetail` or `Skills` declaratively. We keep total control over element order and structure without 'prop drilling'.

3.title: 4. Image Optimization & SEO
3.description: Each project image is **statically imported** to benefit from Next.js's automatic 'Blur Placeholder'. Combined with the dynamic Metadata API (`generateMetadata`), the site offers a premium visual experience and perfect indexing on search engines.

4.title: 5. User Experience & Framer Motion
4.description: Although the core is Server Components, interactivity is handled by **Framer Motion**. I use variants to animate section appearances and hover effects, while ensuring JavaScript weight remains minimal thanks to automatic code-splitting.

5.title: 6. Custom Markdown Rendering Engine
5.description: To keep total flexibility in technical descriptions without depending on a heavy markdown library, I developed a `FormattedText` helper. It intelligently parses bold tags (`**text**`) to highlight key concepts directly in the UI.

homelabs.name: Home Labs
homelabs.fullDescription: Home Labs is a robust and secure self-hosting infrastructure designed to deploy and manage various web services (applications, tools, databases) on a single server. The project philosophy relies on **Security by Default** (no open ports, encrypted tunnel), **Isolation** (containerized services on a dedicated internal network), and **Standardization** (strict folder structure and conventions to ease maintenance).

achievements.0: Zero-Trust Architecture: No open ports (80/443), secure Cloudflare Tunnel
achievements.1: Isolation: Each service runs in isolated Docker containers on a dedicated network
achievements.2: Scalability: Standardized scaffolding for rapid service deployment
achievements.3: Security Hardening: Non-privileged containers and strict resource limits
achievements.4: Automation: Operational scripts for system-wide orchestration
achievements.5: Monitoring: Integrated logging rotation and health checks

homelabs.topology:
The architecture relies on a 5-step secure data flow:

1. **Ingress**: Access via HTTPS to the custom domain.
2. **Cloudflare Edge**: SSL management, DDoS protection, and WAF.
3. **Encrypted Tunnel**: Routing via a persistent outbound connection (Cloudflare Tunnel).
4. **Gateway**: The `cloudflared` container routes the request to the internal service.
5. **Isolated Service**: The target application processes the request on the private `home-labs` Docker network.

0.title: 1. Infrastructure Core & Gateway
0.description: The core of the system resides in the `infrastructure/gateway/` folder. It orchestrates the Cloudflare Tunnel and defines routing rules (hostname -> service:port). Using CF_TUNNEL_TOKEN tokens in a secure `.env` file allows robust authentication without hardcoded secrets.

1.title: 2. Pattern 1: Image-Based Services
1.description: For simple services using official images (e.g., Excalidraw), the configuration is minimalist. It focuses on network isolation and data persistence via named volumes, while respecting CPU/RAM resource limits.

2.title: 3. Pattern 2: Built Services (Custom Apps)
2.description: Home-made applications (e.g., Legal App in Next.js) use a 'Build' pattern. The `docker-compose.yml` points to a local Dockerfile. This optimizes the final image via 'multi-stage builds' to reduce attack surface and image size.

3.title: 4. Pattern 3: Orchestrated Stacks
3.description: Complex services (Cal.com, Typebot) require orchestrating multiple containers (App + DB + Redis). `healthchecks` and `depends_on` are used to ensure the database is ready before the application launches.

4.title: 5. Operational Procedures
4.description: Homelab administration is simplified by master scripts. Adding a service follows a strict workflow: scaffolding via script, DNS config in the Gateway, and deployment via Docker Compose. Maintenance includes log rotation and continuous deployment via pulling new images.

zsh-boost.name: ZSH BOOST
zsh-boost.fullDescription: ZSH BOOST is a modern, modular, and ultra-fast configuration framework designed to offer a 'ready-to-use' ZSH environment. It automates the installation of high-performance CLI tools (eza, bat, fzf, zoxide) and essential productivity plugins. The project philosophy combines power and simplicity: a single configuration file (`config.zsh`) to drive the entire shell experience, while maintaining optimal startup time through lazy-loading and smart dependency detection.

achievements.0: Zero-Config Onboarding: Interactive installer powered by Gum for instant setup
achievements.1: Modular Logic: Granular split between core (Env/Path) and feature modules (Aliases/Utils)
achievements.2: Performance First: Optimized boot sequence with intelligent $PATH management and lazy-loading
achievements.3: Modern Tooling Integration: Native aliases for eza, bat, fd, ripgrep, and zoxide
achievements.4: Extensible Architecture: Private 'local/' layer for custom scripts and sensitive configurations
achievements.5: Automated Maintenance: Global 'up' command to keep Homebrew, plugins, and tools updated

zsh-boost.topology:
The loading flow (Boot Sequence) follows a cascading logic:

1. **Bootstrap** (`.zshrc`): Detects `$ZDOTDIR` via symlink and initializes the environment.
2. **Core Layer** (`core/*`): Defines base variables, ZSH options, and manages `$PATH` without duplicates.
3. **User Config** (`config.zsh`): Reads user preferences (active modules, themes, plugins).
4. **Module Activation** (`modules/*`): Loops through chosen modules to load aliases and functions.
5. **Local Layer** (`local/*`): Loads private customizations and secret tokens outside git.

0.title: 1. Intelligent Boot Mechanism
0.description: The `.zshrc` entry point is designed to be universal. Using `readlink`, it identifies its real location within the file system, allowing ZSH BOOST to be installed anywhere while maintaining robust relative paths for internal dependencies.

1.title: 2. Modular Configuration Management
1.description: All control is done via the `ZSH_MODULES` array. This approach allows activating or deactivating entire feature sets (Git, Docker, Kubernetes, etc.) without touching the source code, simply by upgrading a line in the user configuration file.

2.title: 3. Interactive Scaffolding (Gum UI)
2.description: The `install.sh` script transforms dotfiles installation into a premium experience. Powered by Gum, it offers interactive menus, animated spinners, and theme selectors, automatically managing Homebrew dependencies before linking configuration files.

3.title: 4. Modern Alias Ecosystem
3.description: Aliases are not just shortcuts; they integrate systemic tool checking. If a tool like `eza` is present, `ls` and `ll` commands are augmented; otherwise, the system gracefully falls back to native macOS commands, ensuring the shell never 'breaks'.

4.title: 5. Fully Automated System Update
4.description: The `up` function centralizes maintenance. It not only updates the macOS system; it also synchronizes Oh My Zsh plugins, refreshes Homebrew tools, and updates global package managers (NPM, PNPM, Bun, Rust) in a single action.

portfolio-v1.name: Portfolio V1
portfolio-v1.description: Technical Lab: Discovering Next.js & App Router
portfolio-v1.fullDescription: This project marks my first contact with the **Next.js** ecosystem upon the release of version 13. Designed as a technical laboratory, the goal was to deeply explore the transition from 'Pages' architecture to **App Router**. I tested then-innovative concepts such as **React Server Components (RSC)**, nested layout management, and the early stages of Server Actions. It is on this experimental basis that I forged my understanding of modern React frameworks and server-side performance optimization.

achievements.0: RSC Transition: Experimental migration from client-side architecture to Server Components
achievements.1: App Router Lab: Implementation of nested layouts and complex dynamic routes
achievements.2: Data Fetching Discovery: Exploration of native fetch with deduplication and granular caching
achievements.3: Modern Styling: First steps with Tailwind CSS for a utility-first design system
achievements.4: Fluid Interactions: Integration of Framer Motion for smooth page transitions
achievements.5: Feature Discovery: Testing of <Image> and <Font> tags for automatic asset optimization

portfolio-v1.topology:
The project explores the modular structure of the App Router:

1. **Root Layout**: Centralizing fonts (Next Font) and global metadata.
2. **Nested Architecture**: Using `page.tsx` and `layout.tsx` to isolate sections without reloading the header.
3. **Server-First Fetching**: Retrieving data directly in async components without passing through an internal API.
4. **Optimization Pipeline**: Testing 'Turbopack' and streaming cache for progressive rendering.

0.title: 1. App Router & File-Based Routing
0.description: The major discovery was the `app/` file system. Each folder becomes a route, and each `page.tsx` file an entry point. I explored how shared layouts allow maintaining UI state during navigation.

1.title: 2. React Server Components Discovery
1.description: The shift to server components radically changed my vision of development. By rendering code on the server, I discovered how to drastically reduce the JS bundle sent to the client while simplifying data access.

2.title: 3. Framer Motion Integration
2.description: To compensate for the sometimes static aspect of server rendering, I integrated Framer Motion. The goal was to create smooth transitions between routes and 'staggered' list animations for a premium user experience.

3.title: 4. Performance Optimization Experiment
3.description: I tested the new Next.js APIs for image optimization and local fonts. The objective was to understand how the framework automatically handles Lazy Loading and WebP format without complex configuration.

legal-documentation.name: Legal Platform (LegalApp)
legal-documentation.fullDescription: Legal App is a centralized legal document management hub designed for **Black Rise**. The application automates the generation and editing of legal pages (Legal Notices, TOS, Privacy) via a custom WYSIWYG editor. Powered by **Bun** and **Next.js 16**, it uses a 'Pink Noir' aesthetic with an OKLCH design system. The project stands out for its hybrid architecture: content is persisted in MDX on the filesystem for performance, while authentication and audit trails are orchestrated via **Better Auth** and **Supabase**.

achievements.0: Modern Runtime: Powered by Bun 1.x for ultra-fast execution and Next.js 16 standalone build
achievements.1: Advanced Auth: Better Auth integration with 6 plugins (Passkeys, OTP, Admin, Multi-provider)
achievements.2: WYSIWYG Engine: Custom Tiptap 3.x editor for live MDX content management
achievements.3: Optimized Performance: Server-side MDX compilation with targeted invalidation via updateTag
achievements.4: Security Hardening: 7-layer defense from Cloudflare Edge to isolated Docker volumes
achievements.5: Audit Trail: Full history of content editions tracked in Supabase PostgreSQL

legal-documentation.topology:
The service operates on a highly available 3-tier architecture:

1. **Frontend (Next.js 16)**: Hybrid rendering with static generation (SSG) via `generateStaticParams` and Server Actions for mutations.
2. **Hybrid Persistence**: Content (.mdx) resides on a persistent Docker volume, while metadata and sessions are in the PostgreSQL database.
3. **Edge Security**: Deployed in the homelab under Docker, protected by a Cloudflare Tunnel and Better Auth session guards.

0.title: 1. Advanced Authentication (Better Auth)
0.description: The authentication system uses Better Auth with a multi-plugin configuration. It natively supports Passkeys (WebAuthn), email OTP via Resend, and fine-grained role management (Admin/User). Sessions are synchronized with Next.js cookies for immediate SSR.

1.title: 2. MDX 3.0 Content Pipeline
1.description: Content is not in the database to maximize read performance and portability. `next-mdx-remote` is used to compile Markdown + JSX server-side. A custom pipeline automatically extracts the Table of Contents (TOC) and calculates reading time from frontmatter.

2.title: 3. WYSIWYG Editor with Tiptap
2.description: Administration features a rich editor based on Tiptap 3.x. It allows editing legal documents with complex components (tables, images, code blocks). Upon saving, HTML code is clean converted to Markdown before being persisted on the Docker volume.

3.title: 4. Multi-Layer Security Architecture
3.description: Deployment is armored by 7 security layers. The Dockerfile uses 'standalone' mode with a read-only filesystem, drastically limiting the attack surface. All user inputs are validated by ultra-strict Zod schemas before processing.

personal-linktree.name: Personal Linktree
personal-linktree.fullDescription: This custom 'Link-in-bio' platform centralizes my digital identity and professional activities. Designed as a high-performance showcase, it dynamically aggregates data from multiple APIs (GitHub, LinkedIn, Instagram, YouTube) to offer a real-time 360° view. Using **React 19** and the **React Compiler**, the project achieves exceptional fluidity while maintaining perfect SEO thanks to Server-Side Rendering (SSR). The minimalist aesthetic relies on **Tailwind CSS v4** and a set of custom **shadcn/ui** components.

achievements.0: Lighthouse Mastery: 100/100 on Performance, Accessibility, SEO, and Best Practices
achievements.1: Dynamic Aggregation: Real-time streams via GitHub GraphQL, LinkedIn REST, and Instagram Graph APIs
achievements.2: React 19 Ready: Automatic optimizations via the experimental React Compiler
achievements.3: Modern Styling: Complete migration to Tailwind CSS v4 with OKLCH design system
achievements.4: Interactive Appointment: Self-hosted Cal.com integration via an optimized embed SDK
achievements.5: Server-Side Excellence: Hybrid rendering (RSC) with 1-hour smart caching (ISR)

personal-linktree.topology:
The application follows an optimized hybrid rendering model:

1. **Data Layer (RSC)**: Server components (GitHub, LinkedIn, Instagram) retrieve data directly from APIs with a 3600s ISR cache.
2. **Interactive Layer (Client)**: Carousels (LinkedIn, Projects) and forms use 'use client' for fluid interactivity without sacrificing initial load.
3. **Edge API**: A dedicated API route handles email sending via Resend with server-side Zod validation.
4. **Asset Pipeline**: Next/Image optimization with secure remote patterns for external media.

0.title: 1. Advanced Identity & Contact
0.description: The header centralizes identity (BTS SIO, Apprentice) and contact badges. The form uses a POST API Route validated by Zod. Upon success, a rich email is instantly sent via the Resend SDK to the administrator.

1.title: 2. External API Integration (GitHub/Instagram)
1.description: The data engine aggregates GitHub contributions via GraphQL and the latest Instagram posts via the Graph API. Each section uses Suspense to display a skeleton during asynchronous data loading.

2.title: 3. LinkedIn Carousel & Progress
2.description: A 'smart' client component displays the latest LinkedIn posts (or a static fallback). It features auto-scrolling with a progress bar synchronized via custom CSS keyframes.

3.title: 4. Cal.com Self-Hosted Embed
3.description: The floating 'Book Appointment' button dynamically initializes the Cal.com embed module. It is configured to point to my self-hosted instance with a 'dark' theme and a specific namespace for conversion tracking.
